{{mergefrom|Office 365|discuss=Talk:Microsoft 365#Merger proposal|date=April 2020}} {{Infobox software | name = Microsoft 365 | logo = [[File:Micrososft 365 logo.png|200px]] | logo caption = | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | developer = [[Microsoft]] | released = {{Start date and age|2017|07|10}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2017/07/10/microsoft-puts-partners-center-4-5-trillion-transformation-opportunity/ |title=Microsoft puts partners at the center of $4.5 trillion transformation opportunity |last=Althoff |first=Judson |date=2017-07-10 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2020-04-22}}</ref> | discontinued = | operating system = [[Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | platform = | size = | language = | language count = | language footnote = | genre = [[Software as a service]] contract | license = <!--It is a form of license itself--> | alexa = | website = [https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365 www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365] | standard = | AsOf = }}
'''Microsoft 365''' is a line of [[subscription business model|subscription]] services offered by [[Microsoft]]. The brand was launched on July 10, 2017 for a superset of [[Office 365]] with [[Windows 10]] Enterprise licenses and other cloud-based [[Network security|security]] and [[Mobile device management|device management]] products.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2017/07/10/microsoft-puts-partners-center-4-5-trillion-transformation-opportunity/ |title=Microsoft puts partners at the center of $4.5 trillion transformation opportunity |last=Althoff |first=Judson |date=2017-07-10 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2020-04-22}}</ref>
On April 21, 2020, Microsoft rebranded the Office 365 plans oriented towards consumer and small business markets as Microsoft 365, to emphasize their current inclusion of products and services beyond the core [[Microsoft Office]] software family (including cloud-based productivity tools and [[artificial intelligence]] features).
== History == The brand was first introduced at [[Microsoft Inspire]] in July 2017 as an enterprise subscription product, succeeding the "Secure Productive Enterprise" services released in 2016. They combine [[Windows 10]] Enterprise with [[Office 365]] Business Premium, and the Enterprise Mobility + Security suite, which include Advanced Threat Analytics, [[Microsoft Azure|Azure]] [[Active Directory]], Azure Information Protection, Cloud App Security, and [[Windows Intune]]. Microsoft 365 is sold via Microsoft and its cloud services reseller network.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-wraps-cloud-subscription-services-into-new-microsoft-365-bundles/|title=Microsoft wraps cloud subscription services into new Microsoft 365 bundles|last=Foley|first=Mary Jo|website=ZDNet|language=en|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-follows-office-365-licensing-model-with-new-secure-productive-enterprise-windows-10/|title=Microsoft follows Office 365 licensing model with new 'Secure Productive Enterprise' Windows 10 bundles|last=Foley|first=Mary Jo|website=ZDNet|language=en|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref>
===Consumer and business launch=== On March 30, 2020, Microsoft unveiled a consumer-oriented subscription product under the Microsoft 365 brand for release on April 21,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/21/21229303/microsoft-365-subscriptions-launch-price-release-date-features|title=Microsoft 365 consumer subscriptions now available, most new features coming later|last=Warren|first=Tom|date=2020-04-21|website=The Verge|language=en|access-date=2020-04-21}}</ref> which succeed the existing consumer plans of Office 365. It is a superset of the existing Office 365 products and benefits positioned towards "life", productivity, and families, including the [[Microsoft Office]] suite, 1 TB of additional [[OneDrive]] storage and access to OneDrive Personal Vault, and 60 minutes of [[Skype]] calls per month. Under the brand, Microsoft will also add access to its collaboration platform [[Microsoft Teams|Teams]] (which will also add additional features designed around family use), and a premium tier of [[Microsoft Family Safety]]. Microsoft also announced plans to offer trial offers of third-party services for Microsoft 365 subscribers, with companies such as [[Adobe Inc.|Adobe]] ([[Adobe Creative Cloud|Creative Cloud]] Photography), [[Blinkist]], [[CreativeLive]], [[Experian]], and [[Headspace (company)|Headspace]] having partnered. The services will be sold in "Personal" and "Home" (up to six devices by up to six users) versions, at the same price as their Office 365 counterparts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/30/21199376/microsoft-365-subscriptions-office-family-safety-app-teams-features-price|title=Microsoft aims to win back consumers with new Microsoft 365 subscriptions|last=Warren|first=Tom|date=2020-03-30|website=The Verge|language=en|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/microsofts-office-365-is-now-microsoft-365-a-subscription-for-your-life/|title=Microsoft's Office 365 is now Microsoft 365, a 'subscription for your life'|last=Sherr|first=Ian|website=CNET|language=en|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-rebrands-office-365-consumer-subscriptions-to-m365-adds-more-new-features-for-same-price/|title=Microsoft rebrands Office 365 consumer subscriptions to M365; adds more new features for same price|last=Foley|first=Mary Jo|website=ZDNet|language=en|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2020/03/30/office-365-becomes-microsoft-365-and-gets-new-personal-and-family-plans/|title=Microsoft brings Teams to consumers and launches Microsoft 365 personal and family plans|website=TechCrunch|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref>
Office 365 for small- and medium-sized businesses were also renamed Microsoft 365, including Office 365 Business and ProPlus becoming "Microsoft 365 Apps for business" and "Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise" , Office 365 Business Essentials becoming "Microsoft 365 Business Basic", and Office 365 Business Premium becoming "Microsoft 365 Business Standard" (with the existing Microsoft 365 Business product becoming "Microsoft 365 Business Premium"). The Office 365 brand remains in use for its enterprise, education, healthcare, and governmental plans. Microsoft stated that "over the last several years, our cloud productivity offering has grown well beyond what people traditionally think of as 'Office'”, citing examples such as [[Microsoft Forms|Forms]], [[Microsoft Planner|Planner]], [[Microsoft Stream|Stream]], and Teams.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/blog/2020/03/30/new-microsoft-365-offerings-small-and-medium-sized-businesses/|title=New Microsoft 365 offerings for small and medium-sized businesses|last=Spataro|first=Jared|last2=|first2=|date=2020-03-30|website=Microsoft 365 Blog|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-04-23}}</ref>
== Plans ==
=== Consumer === Aimed at mainstream consumers, both plans offer access to [[Microsoft Office]] applications ([[Microsoft Word|Word]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint]], [[Microsoft Outlook|Outlook]], [[Microsoft Publisher|Publisher]], and [[Microsoft Access|Access]] for home/non-commercial use on one computer ([[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[macOS]], and mobile devices), with access to additional online-based services and premium creative content, 1 TB of [[OneDrive]] storage with Advanced Security, 60 minutes of [[Skype]] international calls per month (subject to area), and partner offers.<ref name="zdnet-o365personal">{{cite web|title=Microsoft adds a new $70 'Personal' SKU to its Office 365 line-up|url=https://www.zdnet.com/microsoft-adds-a-new-70-personal-sku-to-its-office-365-line-up-7000027305/|work=ZDnet|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="engadget-365personal">{{cite web|title=Office 365 Personal now available for $7 per month|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/04/15/office-365-personal/?ncid=rss_truncated|work=Engadget|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Microsoft 365 Family and Personal subscriptions now available for purchase|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-365-family-and-personal-subscriptions-now-available-for-purchase/|last=Foley|first=Mary Jo|website=ZDNet|language=en|access-date=2020-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Compare All Microsoft Office Products {{!}} Microsoft Office|url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-ca/microsoft-365/compare-all-microsoft-365-products|website=www.microsoft.com|language=en-ca|access-date=2020-05-02}}</ref> * '''Microsoft 365 Personal''' (formerly Office 365 Personal): For one computer ([[Personal computer|PC]] or [[Mac OS|Mac]]) and on mobile devices. * '''Microsoft 365 Family''' (formerly Office 365 Home): For up to six devices by up to six users.
=== Small business ===
* '''Microsoft 365 Apps for business''' (formerly Office 365 Business): Offers Office applications for Windows, Mac, and mobile platforms for up to five computers, tablets, and smartphones per user.<ref name=":02">{{cite web|title=Now Available: The New Office 365 Plans for Small and Medium Businesses|url=http://winsupersite.com/office-365/now-available-new-office-365-plans-small-and-medium-businesses|last=Thurrott|first=Paul|date=2 October 2014|website=SuperSite for Windows|publisher=[[Penton Media]]|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref> * '''Microsoft 365 Business Basic''' (formerly Office 365 Business Essentials): Offers access to hosted e-mail ([[Microsoft Exchange Server|Exchange]]), [[SharePoint]], and [[Microsoft Teams]] services, and access to the mobile app and Office Online versions of Outlook, Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote.<ref name=":02" /> * '''Microsoft 365 Business Standard''' (formerly Office 365 Business Premium): Offers Office applications for Windows, Mac, and mobile platforms for up to five computers, tablets, and smartphones per user, as well as hosted Exchange, [[MileIQ]], [[Microsoft Bookings]], SharePoint, and Teams services.<ref name=":02" /><ref name="OppSec">{{cite web|title=Office 2013 Public Preview: Office 365 for Home and Businesses|url=http://www.winsupersite.com/article/office-2013-beta2/office-365-public-preview-office-365-home-businesses-143706|author=Paul Thurrott|date=2012-07-16|work=SuperSite for Windows|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BHw4fqHc?url=http://www.winsupersite.com/article/office-2013-beta2/office-365-public-preview-office-365-home-businesses-143706|archive-date=October 9, 2012|accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref name="pt-365smallbusiness">{{cite web|title=The New Office 365: What’s a Small Business to Do?|url=http://winsupersite.com/office-365/new-office-365-what-s-small-business-do|work=SuperSite for Windows|accessdate=21 March 2013}}</ref> * '''Microsoft 365 Business Premium''' (formerly Mcrosoft 365 Business): Similar to Business Standard, but also including additional security services such as Azure Information Protection, [[Microsoft Intune]] device management, and Office 365 Advanced Threat Protection.
=== Enterprise ===
* '''Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise''' (formerly Office 365 Professional Plus, or ProPlus): Offers access to the Office Professional Plus applications on up to five devices per user.<ref name="pcw-365newplans">{{cite web|title=Microsoft Updates Office 365 for Business, Adds New Plans|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2416012,00.asp|work=PC Magazine|accessdate=21 March 2013}}</ref>
